title: 107_s3096
content: The "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" or the "BLAST Act" aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of all new firearms for sale and those in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITION OF BALLISTICS. The term 'ballistics' means a comparative analysis of fired bullets and cartridge casings to identify the firearm from which they were discharged. SEC. 4. TEST FIRING AND AUTOMATED STORAGE OF BALLISTICS RECORDS. Amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, store records in a database, and store fired bullet and cartridge casings as specified by the Secretary. No civil liability except for civil penalties imposed under this section. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist firearm manufacturers and importers in complying with regulations by providing equipment for ballistics testing and database maintenance. No civil liability except for civil penalties imposed under this section. The Attorney General and the Secretary will provide ballistics equipment, develop a database of ballistics images, offer education on ballistics in firearm crime reduction, coordinate with law enforcement agencies, and take necessary steps to make ballistics testing effective. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for accessing ballistics records, encourage training for examiners, and submit annual reports on the impact of these measures to Congress. The Attorney General and the Secretary will submit annual reports to Congress on the impact of accessing ballistics records, including the number of investigations and prosecutions where the records were valuable, accessibility across jurisdictions, and evaluation of test programs. The Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury are authorized to receive $20,000,000 annually from 2001 to 2004 for ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and mandatory testing of firearms. The Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury are authorized to receive $20,000,000 annually from 2001 to 2004 for ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and mandatory testing of firearms. Additionally, the Secretary and the Attorney General shall conduct mandatory ballistics testing of all firearms obtained or in their possession. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect once the ballistics systems used by the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury are interoperable for mandatory testing of new firearms. The Treasury, with the Board of the National Integrated Ballistics Information Network, certifies interoperability of ballistics systems for mandatory testing of new firearms. Section 923(m)(1) of title 18, US Code, will be effective 5 years after enactment, while section 923(m)(6) will be effective immediately. SEC. 5. PRIVACY RIGHTS OF LAW ABIDING CITIZENS. Ballistics information of individual guns may not be used for prosecutorial purposes unless law enforcement has reasonable belief of a crime and that the information would assist in the investigation.
